latest news.eng_title: Canada's Unemployment Rate Reaches 6.6% in August, Highest in 7 Years
latest news.summary: According to official data released by Statistics Canada, the unemployment rate in Canada has risen to 6.6% in August, the highest level in seven years excluding the COVID-19 pandemic period. This marks a significant increase, and the data suggests that the labor market is experiencing challenges.
latest news.title: Tasa De Desempleo Sube A 6,6% En Canadá En Agosto, La Más Alta En 7 Años

latest news.eng_title: The Unemployment Rate Ticks Lower in August -- Barely
latest news.summary: The U.S. unemployment rate decreased by 0.1 percentage points from July to August, but this change is largely due to rounding. The unemployment rate for August is 4.2%, down from 4.3% in July. Breaking down the numbers, the labor force grew to 168,549,000 in August, while the number of unemployed workers decreased to 7,115,000. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, this is a positive development for the U.S. economy, as the unemployment rate had risen from a 50-year low of 3.4% last year to 4.3% in July, triggering a widely-followed recession indicator.
latest news.title: The Unemployment Rate Ticks Lower in August -- Barely

latest news.eng_title: The unemployment rate fell slightly to 4.2 percent in August: How will investors respond?
latest news.summary: The US unemployment rate fell slightly to 4.2 percent in August, but economists are warning that a recession could be on the horizon. According to the Salm Rule, if the three-month average unemployment rate is half a point or more above the lowest recorded rate, a recession is taking hold. The July Employment Report showed that the labor market is still tight, with 709,000 more workers entering the labor market over the last year, but the number of employed workers has fallen by 66,000. As a result, labor demand is falling, and workers are encountering greater competition. Despite this, the August report may provide some relief, with 142,000 jobs added to the economy. However, investors are still wary, and some have been selling off tech stocks due to worries of a recession. As markets open, it remains to be seen how investors will interpret the news, with some potentially seeing the AI craze as overvalued and a potential threat to their portfolios.
latest news.title: The unemployment rate fell slightly to 4.2 percent in August: How will investors respond?

latest news.eng_title: Swiss Youth Unemployment Rate Increases Amid Mixed Labor Market Trends

Organization: Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Affairs

latest news.summary: According to the latest data from the Swiss State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (Seco), the youth unemployment rate in Switzerland has increased. The unemployment rate rose by 0.1 percentage points to 2.4% in August 2024 compared to the previous month. The number of people looking for work increased by 1146 (+0.6%) to 188,913, while the number of people being laid off decreased by 210 (-8.4%) to 2,293. The number of open job postings increased by 706 (+2.0%) to 35,660. Additionally, the number of people affected by short-time work decreased by 39.0% to 3,871, and the number of affected companies decreased by 22.7% to 235. Seco's data suggests that the labor market is experiencing a mixed trend, with both positive and negative developments.
latest news.title: Die Jugendarbeitslosigkeit in der Schweiz hat zugenommen

latest news.eng_title: Youth Unemployment in Switzerland Increases by 20.2% in August 2024
latest news.summary: The youth unemployment rate in Switzerland increased by 20.2% in August 2024 compared to the previous month. The unemployment rate among 50- to 64-year-olds also increased by 1.6% within a month. In contrast to May 2024, fewer people were registered with the unemployment office in August. The State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (Seco) published the latest labor market data on Thursday morning. The unemployment rate rose by 0.1 percentage points to 2.4% in August 2024 compared to the previous month. In summary, the data shows an increase in youth unemployment and unemployment among older people, as well as an increase in the number of people looking for work, while fewer people were registered with the unemployment office in August compared to May 2024. According to the data, 30,339 people are currently unemployed, with 470 more people unemployed in August 2024 compared to July 2024. The number of job seekers increased by 1,146 (+0.6%) to 188,913 in August 2024, while the number of people who had exhausted their right to unemployment benefits in June 2024 was 2,293, 210 fewer (-8.4%) than in May 2024. The number of open positions decreased by 428 (-1.2%) to 36,246, while the number of open positions increased by 706 (+2.0%) to 35,660 when adjusted for seasonal fluctuations.
latest news.title: August 2024: Die Jugendarbeitslosigkeit in der Schweiz hat zugenommen

latest news.eng_title: Swiss Labor Market Situation in August 2024
latest news.summary: The Swiss Federal Government's Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO) has released its latest report on the labor market situation in Switzerland. In August 2024, the number of unemployed people increased by 3,638 (+3.4%) compared to the previous month, reaching 111,354. Compared to the same month last year, unemployment increased by 21,473 people (+23.9%). The unemployment rate increased by 0.1 percentage points to 2.4% in August 2024. The number of unemployed people adjusted for seasonal variations increased by 1,831 (+1.6%) compared to the previous month, reaching 116,468. The unemployment rate adjusted for seasonal variations remained at 2.5% in August 2024. Between July 2024 and August 2024, the number of young unemployed people (15-24 years old) increased by 2,004 people (+20.2%) to 11,905. Compared to the same month last year, this represents an increase of 2,093 people (+21.3%). The youth unemployment rate increased by 0.5 percentage points to 2.7% in August 2024. In August 2024, the number of unemployed seniors (50-64 years old) was 470 or 1.6% higher than the previous month (30,339). Compared to the same month last year, it increased by 5,189 people (+20.6%). The senior unemployment rate was 2.2% in August 2024, 0.1 percentage points higher than the previous month. Job seekers In August 2024, 180,236 job seekers were recorded, 1,097 people more than the previous month (+0.6%). Compared to the same month last year, this number increased by 27,919 people (+18.3%). The job seeker rate remained at 3.9% in August 2024. In August 2024, the number of job seekers adjusted for seasonal variations increased by 1,146 (+0.6%) compared to the previous month, reaching 188,913. The job seeker rate adjusted for seasonal variations remained at 4.1% in August 2024. Arrivals at the end of benefits According to the data from the end of August 2024, the number of people who exhausted their unemployment benefits in June 2024 was 2,293. This represents 210 people fewer (-8.4%) than in May 2024. Vacant positions In August 2024, 36,246 vacant positions were announced to the employment offices, 428 fewer than the previous month (-1.2%). 17,859 (49.3%) of the positions are subject to the obligation to announce vacant positions. There were 11,120 vacant positions fewer (-23.5%) than at the same time last year. In August 2024, the number of vacant positions adjusted for seasonal variations increased by 706 (+2.0%) compared to the previous month, reaching 35,660. Reduction of working hours According to the data from the end of August 2024, the reduction of working hours affected 3,871 people in June 2024*, 2,480 fewer (-39.0%) than in May 2024. The number of affected companies decreased by 69 (-22.7%) compared to May 2024, reaching 235. *For reasons of payment practice, the data from the unemployment insurance funds on the number of arrivals at the end of benefits/cases of reduction of working hours counted are published with a two-month delay. These figures may still evolve in the future. From August 2024, the SECO will publish its 'Labor Market Situation' documentation for the press in a modernized form in order to present the labor market statistics in a more up-to-date and adapted manner. The content of the publication and its layout have been reviewed. The publication now presents the probability of departure from unemployment and return to professional activity as well as additional statistics on the duration of unemployment. All statistics are presented in clear tables or graphs. Another innovation concerns the production process, which takes place to a large extent in an automated manner. Address for sending questions Fabian Maienfisch, Deputy Head of Communication and Spokesperson SECO, tel. +41 58 462 40 20 Francoise Tschanz, Spokesperson SECO, tel.
latest news.title: La situation sur le marché du travail en août 2024

latest news.eng_title: Swiss Labor Market Situation in August 2024
latest news.summary: The Swiss Federal Government's SECO has released its latest report on the labor market situation in Switzerland. The number of unemployed increased by 3,638 (+3.4%) in August 2024 compared to the previous month, reaching 111,354. Compared to the same month last year, unemployment increased by 21,473 (+23.9%). The unemployment rate rose by 0.1 percentage points to 2.4% in August 2024 compared to the previous month. The seasonally adjusted number of unemployed increased by 1,831 (+1.6%) to 116,468 in August 2024. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate remained at 2.5%. The number of young unemployed (15-24 years old) increased by 2,004 (+20.2%) to 11,905 in August 2024 compared to July 2024. Compared to the same month last year, this represents an increase of 2,093 (+21.3%). The youth unemployment rate rose by 0.5 percentage points to 2.7% in August 2024 compared to the previous month. The number of older unemployed (50-64 years old) was 470 or 1.6% higher than the previous month's value at 30,339. Compared to the same month last year, it increased by 5,189 (+20.6%). The unemployment rate for older workers was 2.2% in August 2024, 0.1 percentage points higher than the previous month. A total of 180,236 job seekers were registered in August 2024, 1,097 more than in the previous month (+0.6%). Compared to the same month last year, this number increased by 27,919 (+18.3%). The job seeker rate remained at 3.9% in August 2024. The seasonally adjusted number of job seekers increased by 1,146 (+0.6%) to 188,913 in August 2024 compared to the previous month. The seasonally adjusted job seeker rate remained at 4.1%. According to data as of August 2024, the number of people who had exhausted their right to unemployment benefits in June 2024 was 2,293. This is 210 people fewer (-8.4%) than in May 2024. There were 36,246 open positions reported to the RAV in August 2024, 428 fewer than in the previous month (-1.2%). 17,859 (49.3%) of these positions are subject to notification. Compared to the same period last year, a total of 11,120 fewer open positions were counted (-23.5%). Seasonally adjusted, there was an increase of 706 open positions (+2.0%) to 35,660 in August 2024 compared to the previous month. According to data as of August 2024, 3,871 people were affected by short-time work in June 2024, 2,480 fewer (-39.0%) than in May 2024. The number of affected companies decreased by 69 (-22.7%) to 235 compared to May 2024. The SECO will modernize its press documentation 'The Situation on the Labor Market' starting in August 2024, with the goal of presenting labor market statistics in a more targeted and up-to-date manner. The publication has been revised in terms of content and layout. New content includes, among other things, the probability of leaving unemployment for employment and additional statistics on the duration of unemployment. All statistics are presented in clear tables and/or graphs. The production process now runs largely automatically.
latest news.title: Die Lage auf dem Arbeitsmarkt im August 2024

latest news.title: Youth unemployment rate drops to 8.85%

news knowledge.eng_title: China On The Verge: Welfare State Crumbles, Explosion In Social Unrest As Youth Unemployment Soars, Strikes Surge
news knowledge.summary: China's economy is facing a severe slowdown, with youth unemployment soaring to a record 21.3% in August 2023, and the overall unemployment rate increasing to 5.2% in July 2024. The government has attempted to downplay the issue by changing the way unemployment data is reported, but experts believe that the numbers are being manipulated to hide the true extent of the problem. The rise in unemployment is particularly concerning among young jobseekers, with a record 11.79 million tertiary graduates entering the labor market in 2024. Many fresh graduates have had to scale back their salary expectations by a third due to the economic downturn. Labor strikes have increased by 3% in the first half of 2024, with 80% of incidents involving the property and manufacturing sectors. Worker unrest is a reflection of the growing pressures on the economy, with many workers facing long working hours, low wages, and limited social security coverage. The government has vowed to improve the social security system, but experts believe that this will be a difficult task, and that a stimulus bazooka may be necessary to address the issue.
news knowledge.title: China On The Verge: Welfare State Crumbles, Explosion In Social Unrest As Youth Unemployment Soars, Strikes Surge

news knowledge.eng_title: Youth Unemployment in China Reaches Record High
news knowledge.summary: According to Reuters, citing data from China's National Bureau of Statistics, the youth unemployment rate in China reached 17.1% in July, the highest level since the beginning of the year. This is significantly higher than the 13.2% recorded in June. The record high for youth unemployment was set in June 2023, at 21.3%. However, after this, the Chinese authorities decided to suspend the publication of these data and adjust the methodology for calculating them, excluding students from this group. In the July 2024 data, students are not included, but Reuters notes that the June university graduates, who are estimated to be around 12 million, likely had an impact on the July figures. These graduates entered the labor market, making it even more challenging for young people to find employment. The unemployment rate for the 25-29 age group in July was 6.5%, slightly higher than the 6.4% recorded in June. The overall unemployment rate in China is 5.2%.
news knowledge.title: Безработица среди молодежи в Китае достигла самого высокого уровня с начала года

news knowledge.eng_title: China's Youth Unemployment Rate Rises to 17.1%
news knowledge.summary: China's unemployment rate among youth has risen to 17.1% in July, the highest level this year, according to official data. The numbers show a significant increase in unemployment among young people, aged 16-24, compared to 13.2% in June. This rate peaked at 21.3% in June 2023, after around 12 million university graduates entered the job market in China, increasing competition in a difficult job market. China is facing increasing youth unemployment, as well as a real estate sector burdened with debt and trade issues with the West. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang has called for listening to struggling companies and addressing their difficulties. 'We need to listen to the voices of struggling companies and help them overcome their difficulties,' Li said.
news knowledge.title: الصين: البطالة ترتفع إلى 17.1 %

news knowledge.eng_title: China youth unemployment jumps to 17.1 percent in July
news knowledge.summary: China's youth unemployment rate surged to 17.1 percent in July, the highest level this year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS). This is up from 13.2 percent in June and marks a significant increase from the 21.3 percent peak in June 2023. Chinese Premier Li Qiang called for struggling companies to be 'heard' and 'their difficulties truly addressed.' The unemployment rate among 25- to 29-year-olds stood at 6.5 percent, while the overall unemployment rate was 5.2 percent. However, the NBS figures only account for urban areas, providing an incomplete picture of China's employment situation. The data comes amid other disappointing economic indicators, including dampened industrial production and declining real estate prices. International challenges, such as trade barriers imposed by the European Union and the United States, are also mounting.
news knowledge.title: China youth unemployment jumps to 17.1 percent in July

news knowledge.eng_title: Youth Unemployment in China Rises Sharply
news knowledge.summary: According to China's national statistics bureau, youth unemployment has risen significantly to 13.2% in the latest month, a substantial increase from the previous month's 13.2%. This surge in unemployment highlights the ongoing challenges facing the world's second-largest economy, including unrest in the real estate market, a trade war, and a decline in consumer confidence. The current numbers and previous trends show that youth unemployment has reached its highest point since the beginning of the year, when the statistics bureau introduced a new measurement method. This change in methodology, which excludes students from the youth unemployment figures starting from December 2023, has led to a decrease in reported youth unemployment rates. However, the actual numbers may be higher, as the previous record high of 21.3% in June last year is no longer reported separately due to the claimed improvement in the measurement method.
news knowledge.title: Jeugdwerkloosheid in China stijgt snel

news knowledge.eng_title: China's Youth Unemployment Rate Rises to 17.1% in July
news knowledge.summary: China's youth unemployment rate has risen to 17.1% in July, according to official data, the highest level this year. The country is facing increasing headwinds, including rising youth unemployment, a real estate sector burdened with debt and commercial issues with the West, according to AFP. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang called on struggling companies to 'seriously address their difficulties', according to state news agency Xinhua. The data from the National Bureau of Statistics showed a significant increase in the youth unemployment rate among those aged 16-24, compared to 13.2% in June. The rate had peaked at 21.3% in June 2023, before the authorities stopped releasing the data and changed their methodology, excluding students. Approximately 12 million students graduated from university in China in June this year, leading to increased competition in a tough job market, which may explain the sharp rise in unemployment in July. President Xi Jinping had announced in May that fighting youth unemployment should be a 'top priority'. The data is disappointing, with the youth unemployment rate among those aged 25-29 rising to 6.5% in July, compared to 6.4% in the previous month. The overall unemployment rate was 5.2%. However, the statistics from the National Bureau of Statistics do not provide a complete picture of the employment situation in China, as they only consider urban areas. The new unemployment data comes after other disappointing Chinese economic data, including industrial production figures that show a decline, despite recent government measures to boost growth. Trade barriers are also increasing, with industrial production growth slowing to 5.1% in July, compared to 5.3% in June, and below expectations. Major cities in China have also seen a further decline in property prices last month, indicating a slowdown in demand. Additionally, demand for bank loans has fallen for the first time in around 20 years, according to official data released earlier this week.
news knowledge.title: ارتفاع معدل البطالة بين الشباب في الصين إلى 17,1% في يوليو

news knowledge.eng_title: China's Youth Unemployment Rate Rises to 17% in July
news knowledge.summary: China's youth unemployment rate has risen to 17% in July, according to official data, reaching its highest level this year. The country is facing increasing winds of adversity, including rising youth unemployment, a real estate sector burdened with debt, and commercial problems with the West. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang called for 'serious treatment' of struggling companies, according to state news agency Xinhua. The data from the National Bureau of Statistics showed a significant increase in the youth unemployment rate, compared to 13.2% in June. The rate had peaked at 21.3% in June 2023 before the authorities stopped releasing the data and changed their methodology, excluding students. Approximately 12 million university graduates finished their studies in China in June this year, leading to increased competition in a tough job market, which may explain the sharp rise in unemployment in July. President Xi Jinping had announced in May that combating youth unemployment should be a 'top priority.' The overall unemployment rate was 5.2%. However, the statistics from the National Bureau of Statistics only provide a partial picture of the employment situation in China, as they only consider urban areas. The new unemployment data comes after other disappointing Chinese economic data, including industrial production figures that show weakness, despite recent government measures to boost growth. Industrial production growth slowed to 5.1% in July, compared to 5.3% in June, falling short of analysts' expectations. Major cities in China also saw a decline in property prices last month, indicating a slowdown in demand. Additionally, demand for bank loans declined for the first time in about 20 years, according to official data released earlier this week. The country is facing increasing international challenges, including increased trade barriers imposed by the European Union and the United States to protect their markets from Chinese low-cost products and what they consider unfair competition.
news knowledge.title: بطالة شابة في الصين تزيد أوجاع ثاني أكبر اقتصاد في العالم

news knowledge.eng_title: China's youth unemployment rate jumps to 17.1% in July after recent declines
news knowledge.summary: China's youth unemployment rate surged to 17.1% in July, up from 13.2% in June, according to official data. This increase follows a three-month decline in unemployment rates. The rise in youth unemployment coincides with the entry of millions of recent graduates into the job market during the Chinese summer. The worsening youth unemployment comes as China's urban unemployment rate also rose to 5.2% in July from 5% in June, indicating the country's economy is struggling to grow rapidly. 'The worsening youth unemployment comes as millions of recent graduates enter the job market during the Chinese summer and comes after a series of indicators show the world's second-largest economy is struggling to grow more rapidly.'
news knowledge.title: China's youth unemployment rate jumps to 17.1% in July after recent declines

news knowledge.eng_title: China's youth unemployment hits new high amid economic challenges
news knowledge.summary: China's youth unemployment rate has hit a new high of 17.1% in July, up from 13.2% in June, according to the country's statistics bureau. This sharp increase reflects a broader slowdown in the economy, with employers hesitant to hire due to various economic challenges. The employment landscape has become increasingly competitive, with 12 million students graduating this summer and top universities' candidates vying for remote rural area roles. The July rate is the highest recorded since December 2023, when officials adjusted the methodology. In contrast, the services sector provided a glimmer of hope, with employment rising at its fastest pace in 11 months, according to the Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers' index survey. However, concerns persist about the impact of youth unemployment on the broader economic stability and the Communist Party's leadership.
news knowledge.title: China's youth unemployment hits new high amid economic challenges

news knowledge.eng_title: China's Youth Unemployment Rate Hits 17.1% in July
news knowledge.summary: China's youth unemployment rate reached 17.1% in July, up from 13.2% the previous month, according to the country's statistics bureau. The economy, valued at 19,000 billion dollars, is facing a series of challenges, including a trade war, a prolonged housing crisis, and cautious consumer confidence, which have led to a slowdown in hiring. The job market has become increasingly competitive for young Chinese, with approximately 12 million students graduating this summer. Even rural job postings are being sought after by young graduates from top universities, highlighting the severity of the employment situation. The youth unemployment rate was previously at a record high of 21.3% in June last year, but the data was suspended due to concerns about including students still in school. The July unemployment rate is the highest since December 2023, following a change in methodology used to calculate the statistics. For those aged 25-29, the unemployment rate was 6.5% in July, while it was 3.9% for those aged 30-59, excluding students. A recent survey of factory managers showed that the manufacturing sector remains reluctant to hire new workers, with the employment gauge in this sector not having improved since February 2023. However, the services sector has provided some hope, with employment increasing in July at the fastest pace in 11 months, according to the Caixin/S&P Global survey of service sector purchasing managers. This increase may bring some optimism to policymakers concerned about the potential economic and social impact of high youth unemployment rates.
news knowledge.title: Le chômage des jeunes en Chine atteint 17,1 % en juillet Par Investing.com
